docs.snippet: Keye Luke, an actor who first gained notice as the brash but earnest No. 1 Son in the Charlie Chan detective films of the 1930's and 40's, died on Saturday at Presbyterian Intercommunity Hospital in Whittier, Calif. He was 86 years old and lived i...
docs.lead_paragraph: Keye Luke, an actor who first gained notice as the brash but earnest No. 1 Son in the Charlie Chan detective films of the 1930's and 40's, died on Saturday at Presbyterian Intercommunity Hospital in Whittier, Calif. He was 86 years old and lived in Whittier. He died of a stroke, a family spokesman said.

headline.main: Keye Luke, Actor, Is Dead at 86; 'No. 1 Son' and 'Kung Fu' Master

docs.snippet: A former Newark housing official faces up to 15 years in prison and $750,000 in fines after he pleaded no contest on Friday to three charges of mail fraud. He is to be sentenced on March 18. Four of the seven charges against the official, Oscar Ja...
docs.lead_paragraph: A former Newark housing official faces up to 15 years in prison and $750,000 in fines after he pleaded no contest on Friday to three charges of mail fraud. He is to be sentenced on March 18. Four of the seven charges against the official, Oscar James, were dismissed, including an accusation that he embezzled $5,000 in Newark funds while he was executive assistant to the city Director of General Services. Mr. James, 33 years old, of Newark, was accused of having city carpenters and an electrician use city supplies to repair an apartment of a city secretary with whom he had a daughter.

byline.original: By James R. Kincaid; James R. Kincaid has written books on Dickens, Tennyson and Trollope

docs.snippet: I was a student of Richard Ellmann's at Oxford in the early 1970's, and spent many afternoons in his gloomy, cavernous study at New College, working my slow way through "Finnegans Wake." Lost in the maze of Joyce's hermetic "night language," I wou...
docs.lead_paragraph: I was a student of Richard Ellmann's at Oxford in the early 1970's, and spent many afternoons in his gloomy, cavernous study at New College, working my slow way through "Finnegans Wake." Lost in the maze of Joyce's hermetic "night language," I would stare at the row of pale-green Dublin phone books on the shelf behind Ellmann's desk and speculate about what made him so . . . Joycean. Outwardly the eminent biographer of Joyce could hardly have been more different from his subject. Joyce was, in his own words, "a small man, prone to alcoholism"; Ellmann was a moderate drinker and a rather bulky man, with a balding brow and a flat Midwestern accent that years of dining at High Table with murmurous Oxford dons had failed to mitigate. Maybe it was his effortless fidelity to his own nature that made him such a shrewd interpreter of others. Ellmann treated his subjects -- William Butler Yeats, James Joyce, Oscar Wilde -- with a benign, avuncular tolerance. He noted, and forgave, their failings. Even the title of his biographical essays on the major modernists, "Golden Codgers" -- the phrase is from Yeats -- reflected his affection for the writers to whom he devoted his life. Ellmann was drawn to genius, yet was himself an ordinary man -- the Leopold Bloom of biography. What made Ellmann's biography of Joyce the masterpiece that it is? Not every great writer earns a great biography. Hemingway has been ill-served by Carlos Baker and Kenneth S. Lynn, among others. Joseph Conrad lies crushed beneath the weight of Frederick Karl's tombstone-sized biography, while J. R. Ackerley, a minor literary journalist in the London of the 1940's, has been resurrected in Peter Parker's marvelous biography. Who reads the works of Baron Corvo now? We read the work of his biographer, A. J. A. Symons (himself the subject of an excellent biography by his brother, Julian). What matters, in the end, is how passionately the biographer responds to the life he's writing about, how deeply it taps into his own preoccupations. "A good biography is prompted not by the inherent qualities of its subject," argued Julian Symons in his introduction to his brother's book "The Quest for Corvo," "but by the biographer's unconsciously realized opportunity for self-expression." In Joyce, Ellmann found a subject who elicited his own gifts.

byline.original: By James Atlas; James Atlas is an editor of The New York Times Magazine; he is at work on a biography of Saul Bellow

docs.snippet: The young and energetic Oscar Orbos, newly appointed executive secretary to President Corazon C. Aquino, is expected to work varying miracles on behalf of a faltering administration facing severe economic difficulties.    In his new job, which is ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The young and energetic Oscar Orbos, newly appointed executive secretary to President Corazon C. Aquino, is expected to work varying miracles on behalf of a faltering administration facing severe economic difficulties. In his new job, which is sometimes called "the deputy presidency," he is Mrs. Aquino's John H. Sununu, in charge of coordinating the entire range of Government policy.

headline.main: Aquino's New Chief of Staff Is Raising Hopes in Manila

byline.original: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: DURING the summer of 1973, everything, it seemed, changed for Nye Heron. Between semesters of law school at the University of London, the Dublin-born Mr. Heron, then 21, was supposed to take a job in the student program of a camp for Jewish childr...
docs.lead_paragraph: DURING the summer of 1973, everything, it seemed, changed for Nye Heron. Between semesters of law school at the University of London, the Dublin-born Mr. Heron, then 21, was supposed to take a job in the student program of a camp for Jewish children in upstate New York. Salary: $40 a week; no smoking on Saturdays. Instead, Mr. Heron stopped by the Irish Arts Center, which an uncle, Brian Heron, had founded in his Upper West Side apartment in Manhattan a year earlier. "He gave me a job for $40 a week and I could smoke on Saturdays," Mr. Heron recently recalled.

headline.main: Adding Irish Sensibility On Stage and in Films

docs.snippet: The story behind "Rodrigo D: No Future" is dramatic, disturbing and true. In 1988, Victor Manuel Gaviria, a Colombian poet and short-film maker, directed this fictional feature based on the violent lives of young people in the drug- and crime-fill...
docs.lead_paragraph: The story behind "Rodrigo D: No Future" is dramatic, disturbing and true. In 1988, Victor Manuel Gaviria, a Colombian poet and short-film maker, directed this fictional feature based on the violent lives of young people in the drug- and crime-filled city of Medellin. Of the nine nonprofessional actors he cast in major roles, six are now dead, obscure victims of the small-time crime that ruled their lives. Mr. Gaviria's film, which opens today at the Public Theater, adroitly avoids sensationalizing its already explosive subject. The meandering plot reflects the aimlessness of Rodrigo and his friends, who spend their days making minor drug deals and stealing cars. The most serious events happen off screen. One character arrives and tells his friends he has shot a policeman; before long, the friends hear that a mysterious jeep has taken him away.

headline.main: Review/Film; Living in a Violent World

docs.snippet: The British singer and songwriter Phil Collins, the producer Quincy Jones and a pop newcomer, the singer Mariah Carey, garnered the most nominations for the 33d annual Grammy Awards. The nominations were announced yesterday by the National Academy...
docs.lead_paragraph: The British singer and songwriter Phil Collins, the producer Quincy Jones and a pop newcomer, the singer Mariah Carey, garnered the most nominations for the 33d annual Grammy Awards. The nominations were announced yesterday by the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences. Mr. Collins received eight nominations in the 77 Grammy categories. His song about homelessness, "Another Day in Paradise," was nominated as song of the year, an award given to songwriters, and record of the year, an award given to a single. Mr. Collins's ". . . But Seriously," was nominated as album of the year.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: NATIONAL ACADEMY OF RECORDING ARTS AND SCIENCES

docs.snippet: For the fourth time in four seasons, the 92d Street Y's Lyrics and Lyricists series is devoting all five programs to a single composer or team. This year, the subject is Richard Rodgers, who follows Cole Porter, the Gershwins and Irving Berlin in ...
docs.lead_paragraph: For the fourth time in four seasons, the 92d Street Y's Lyrics and Lyricists series is devoting all five programs to a single composer or team. This year, the subject is Richard Rodgers, who follows Cole Porter, the Gershwins and Irving Berlin in the songwriters examined. Although the formula developed by the series's artistic director, Maurice Levine, has become very set, it hasn't lost its appeal. An unabashedly upbeat mixture of nostalgia, biography and light musicology, the programs blend musical performances, narration, slides, and film clips into a celebratory overview of their subjects.

headline.main: Review/Music; Richard Rodgers Series at Y, With Songs and Narration

docs.snippet: It started as a desperate idea to fill some television time during the 1987 writers' strike in Hollywood; now the comeback of "Dark Shadows" is the great prime-time hope of NBC.    The cult-hit soap opera, which made a romantic hero out of a reluc...
docs.lead_paragraph: It started as a desperate idea to fill some television time during the 1987 writers' strike in Hollywood; now the comeback of "Dark Shadows" is the great prime-time hope of NBC. The cult-hit soap opera, which made a romantic hero out of a reluctant but voracious vampire named Barnabas Collins, will be reborn on NBC starting as a two-part mini-series Sunday and Monday nights at 9.

headline.main: NBC Puts New Blood In Old Vampire Series

byline.original: By BILL CARTER, Special to The New York Times
